The citizens of Providence. Rhode Island,
says the New-York Christian Advocate,
sent an agent to this city, last week. who
purchased a quantity os DR.. Chambers
medicine, for the use of such unfortunate
victims of intemperance as are unable to
procure it themselves. The agent related
to us several affecting instances of its res
toratlve powers. A man who had long beeu
confirmed drunkard, by using the med-
cine four days, was thoroughly reclaimed,
and is now perfectly temperate. and very
Industrious and respectable. Another. an
ingenious mechanic. who. in consequence OF
his incorporate habits, had forfeited the
confidence OF the public, has t;een restored
to his family and to society, and is now
proitaby employed, with several men nn-
der his direction. Many other instances the
agent mentioned ofts salutary effects, The
citizens of Providence have set an example
which is worthy of universal imitation
And it gives us pleasure to state, that the
Captain of tine steamboat Washington Of
fered free passage to their agent, as soon
as he understood the benevolent object oi
his mission

FOR SALE Al
ROBERTSON & LTTTLE'S
LOTTERY OFFICE,

| Pursuant to public notice, large and respect
able meeting of the Democratic Republican
friends of the Administration of the General Gov
ernmert in Newcastle County, assembled at
the Red Lion Inn on Saturday the 18th day Of
July, when


Gen. WILLIAM CooCH, was called so the
chair, and GIDEON JAoUEs, was appointed Sec
retaiy.


After very suitable and lucid EXPOSITION of the
object Of the meeting, by DR.. Arnold Naudain,
II was, on motion,


HeSolred, That Committee of five be ap.
pointed by the Chairman, for the purpose of re-
porting resolutions for the consideration of this
meeting


In pursuance whereof, the chairman appoint
cd Messrs. Arnold Naudain, Wm p. l,robson,
John Higgins, VIM. Kennedy, and Alexander
Crawford.


The committee reported the following resolu-
tons, which, after some explanatory remarks.
were unanimously adopted.


Resoiuea, That We recognize in John Quincy
Adams Statesman Of unquestioned abilities, of
great experience and of rreproachable charac-
ter; who has enjoyed the confidence of WASH
ington, Jefferson, Madison and Monroe, in long
course Of meritorous and active public service,
eminently calculated to prepare for the duties of
the first civil Office in the country; whose pri-
vate life, in all its relations, presents example





overlooked in the selection of Republican
Chief Magistrate; that in reviewing the measures
Of his administration we can discover no act
whatever which do not meet our decided ap-
| probation, and that we will, therefore, use all
fair and honorable means to support his admins
traton, and to secure his reelection.
Res0ioed, That the appointment of HeNry
Clay to the office of Secretary of State, was but
a tribute due to the high character, splendid
talents and ardent patriotism of that great and
distinguished Satesman--that the stale charge
of corruption which has been founded upon that
appointment, is contradcted by all we know of
the most eminent persons it concerns, and by all
the circumstances involved in the case, while it
IL unsupported BY any evidence which would be
admitted to the prejudice ofany credi1able man
in society.


HesolOed, That the temperance, forbearance
and iirmness displayed by the President of the
United states towards the Governor OF Georgia.
under circumstances of provocaton and indigni-
ty Which we believe have had no parallel in the
history Of our country, give him new titles to our
regatd and appreciation.


Hesoiged, That William Cooch, John Ways
William =. Brobson, Robert Porter, Richard
Mansfield and William Kennedy be appointed r
committee for the purpose of corresponding
with such committees may be appointed by
the Democratic Republican friends of the adj
mnstraton in the respective counties of this
State.


Aes0ived, That the proceedings of this meet.
ing be signed By the Chairman and Secretary.
and published in the American Watchman, the
Delaware Journal, and the Wilmingtonian.


Reso!rcd, That this meeting now adjourn to
meet at this place on Saturday, the first day Of
September next.


wM. CooCH, Chairman.


GIDEoN JAouEs, Secry.
Public Meeting.

We learn that on Tuesday evening, the
caDtsin aud mate of vessel from Folly
Landing, fought duel 7oith aces, on the
deck of their vessel. They hacked one an
otberin fine style; but some OF the specta-
tors having little regard for this honorable
method of settling disputes, had them carri-
ed before a magistrate.


The dangers to which many persons were
exposed on Wednesday afternoon, were
much greater than we were aware OF. A
steamboat that left the upper wharf at
Camden, weathered the storm with difficult
t. The water rushed into the cabin win
dow, the awning was torn to rags, and a
company of nearly two hundred persons,
principally women and children. remained
exposed during the whole the storm. 9th
er steam and team boats were Oh the river,
but this appears to have been exposed to
most danger, as it was feared She would be
dashed against the wharf, i'll which case she
would probably have sunk.


A boat capsiZed near the Navy Yard, and
If five boys that were on board, three were
drowned. The editor Of the U. 5. Gazette
says that he witnessed the upsetting OF an
other boat few minutes after 1t lett the
wharf Two young men who were III It, got
on the keel and were saved.


A young woman standing on the edge OF
South street wharf, awaiting the approach
of friend, was so much startled by the ex-
poslon of cracker, which a mi schicvous
boy threw at her feet, that she fell into the
river and was drowned before assistance
could be rendered.


At the celebration at Germantown, Pa. on
the Fourth If July, Mr.. Bnddey lost his
hand. This accident, we understood, was
occasionce by attempting to fire off can
non number of time in quick succession,
whereby the piece became so heated that
the man who had his fingcr on the touch
hole was obliged to remove it, The explo-
sion took place as soon as the atmosphe-
ric air came in contact WITH the heated pow
der.

FOURTH OF JULY ACCIDEN rs.
From the Phiiadelhhia Gazette.

The present Pacha Jf Egypt was very iesirous
70 obtain the luxury of eating ice, and there be-
ing no such thing in Egypt, Mr.. Salt, the Brit
ish Consul General sent to England for an appa-
ratus for making it. The machine was convey
ed on its arrival to the Pachas palace, and the
Nile water made use of for the purpose. Nah
mond Ali, hung over the whole operation with
the most intense curiosity; and when, after sew
eral disappointments, large piece of real ice
was produced, he took it eagerly in his hands,
danced round the room for ~ like ch j, and
then ran into the iIarem, to snow it to his wives
and ever luxuriatcs upon it.

A most shocking instance of savage tero-
city was perpetrated on Saturday last, in
this place, by the mother Of young girl
assisted by a monster who had, tor some
time, resided as bo4rdrr in the house. l!
appears that the mother, for some trivial Of
fence, inflicted severe cOrporeal punishment
upon the girl; and not being satisfied with
what she had done. asked the gentleman To
finish the work; which, nothing loath, he un
dertook; (for we hear he had repeatedly
tried his hand at the same business,) and
with such effect did he ply his kicks and
cuffs that the victim Of their cruelty died
the next day. a Coroner's inquest was
held upon the body, and verdict given that
her death was caused by excessive beating.
The unfecling wretchcs have both been
consigned, by the proper authority, TO the
County Jail. there to await punishment
which IS justly due them

Thursday, July l9, 1927.

In one ofthe recent discussions in the British
House of Lords on the Spring Gun Bill, Lord
Suffield said-"N longer ago than yesterday a
noble lord had informed him that a gentleman
had contryed very ingenius spring gun for his
house, by which he Mad shot himself, his wife and
his daughter" The Earl of Abingdon, in reply,
said she could not help rising, as the noble Lord
looked at him so earnestly, toinfor.n their Lord
ships that he had not shot his wife and daughter


A laugh.] lie wished also to state to the noble
Lord, that If he found him entering his house.
he would shoot him, and leave him to prove at
terwarls that on entering it he intended no harm,
and to find his remedy farb being shot" Ia laugh

Mr.. Ejiitor-In your last paper observe
letter Of advice to the Watering Commit
tee, but as those gentlemen will doubtless have
enough to attend to without noticing the
wh,ms oil every theorist who chooses to push
forward his opinion, will undertake to in
form your correspondent @ that he is 1T
tie mistaken. He informs the Committee
that eve are entitled by the purchase to all
the water that can flow through certain
aperture, say 1o5 inches;" this, believe, is
not the fact--the power Of the mill is not dc
fined in that way, but if my information be
correct the mill is allowed a good and suth-
cient head of water for driving a stone of GER
tain dimensions, w..h the necessary ma
chinery for manufacturing -four. AS the case


is thus circumstanced, and the power OF the
mill thus defined, the Committee would not
be warrantable in taking the water until al
ter il had been expended on the wheel; and
as the pump will only have to lift the water
bv atmospheric pressure about four feet,
can see no serious difficulty in the case.
cannot see that it will make the machinery
much more complicated, or any more ex-
pensiye. If the water wheel cxert5 the
same power on the pump that it formerly
did on the mill stone, it is all the Committee
have any right to expect; and the quantity
of water furnished they must DC sa'lsaea
with, be it more or less.


As to the plan that has been adopted,
have no doubt the Committee have taken
the advice of those much better qualified to
iudee than / am, and perhaps as weli as
YOUR correspondent Q. himself I.

grass. hopper, which ilutters with So much
yivacity through our meadows during the
autumn, feeds upon vegetable matter. and
deposits its eggs upon vegetables, tor the
purpose OF being supported until maturetl.--
Before the grass-hopper takes wing, anoth-
vr insect, the ichneumon, alights upon its
body, and thrusts under its skin number of
its eggs, by means OF tubular awl. shap
ri uyiduct. These eggs slowly acquire per-
/ tectinn, become living worms, and feed up
on the body Of the hap!eis grass-hopper, un-
! I'll themselves are II ady to take wing. So
admirably do they perform their office, that
they 90 not injure the vital organs of the IN
sect they are internally Sevo' ,iGg, until they
are Just ready to change their state; and At
the proper season, hundreds of grass-hop
pers, in this condition have Just strength
enough rcniaiung to autter to a tree or
fence, and with Il dyingo fort Fix their book


ed feet SO iirmiy as to retain their position
long after death. Examine thcir bodies 1T
tnl, season, and you will find IN empty shell,
r one filled with large and active worms,
! just ready TO burs. their coverings aud be-
cone winged insects


| lac recently p'Ibiishcd number OF the
I North American Retiew supplies us with
!
! little kNowu to common readers, though said
to be familiar to the sight Of those who nav-
igatc between the tropics, the beautiful and
cnignatical insect, commonly called the l'or-
tugurzc man-of- war. 1t is from memoir
To Doctor Tlosns who accompanied Mr.. de
Kruscnstcrp, in his voyage round the world.


"Ihis singular animal hid several times
been delineatcd, described, and endowed
with names, yet not only its denominations
were various. but also the nature and char
actcristics asrubed to it. According to
some it was Poiypus. according to others
a Ioophyte, and others ranged ii among the
Mullusca. Naturalists who followed in the
steps of Lime, have called it the Physalis.
Wonderful as are all the works oil Provi-
dence, admirably fitted as are the several
parts Of each created being for their sever
al functions, complex in their composition as
they at first seem, while vet they are always
found to be really so simple and situable in
their action, on a nearer investigation. we
may, nevertheless, venture to rank this lit
tie animated creat"re among the most curl.
ous phenomenal. A worm between and s
inches in length, which is found but in cer-
tain latitudcs, has seemingly the skill and
knowledge OF an experienced navigator, and
is in itself Little 81 ip. Its evolutons are
according t@ the winds; il r Asses and lowers
It's sal, which is a membrane provided with
clevating and depressingprg ans. When nj
led with air, it is SO light, that it swims on
the surface OF alcohol. and is at the same
time provided with structure. which fur
nishes It witn the necessary ballast.


When ,irh winds would endaDgcr its ex-
iStence, it tlescends into the deep, and is new
e, Sc en- on tie surface Of the water. From the
under side ef the body proceed tubes, which
extend twenty feet in length, and are SO
elastic and delicate, that they wind IN sPi-
raj form like screw, serving at once as an
chors, defensive ard Offensive weapons. pu-
cunatic tubes and ferlels. The insect has
the colcrs of the rainbow; its crest, which
performs the office of sail, IS intersectcd
with pink and blue veins, trimmed with
rosy border, and swells with the wind, or at
the animals pleasure. The iibres contain
a viscous matter, which has the properly OF
stinsing like uettles, and produces pustli!es.
1t acts so strongly, that vessels ~ which
they have been kept for time must be re-
peatcdly washed before they can be used
These !ibrcs NAV be cut Of without dcpriv-
ing them or the rest of the insect OF the prin-
cipe of life; and the separation takes place
spontaneously, whenever the glutinous mat
ter comes in contact with a hard surface,
like the sides Of glass globe. The insect
has, however, dangerous enemies in small
dolphins, aud medes2, against which nei-
ther It's nautical skill nor IT'S poison can de-
fend it. To the natural philosopher, this
little animal is curious cxempliiicatlon OF
the principles of hydrostatics and othygrom-
etry, as its bladder is perhaps among the
substances that can be used for the delicate
instruments Of the latter science. 10 the
ihysologist It has some importance as the
rest of that class of beings, of which every
part is endowed with an uncommonly strong
principle of vitality, and which have there
fore not improperly been called biola by Dr.
Hill. To a contemplatve mind, the won
derful organization of the Physaiis must be
a new proof that hardly any great effort OF
human Ingenuity, perseverance,, courage ana
skill, is without duplicate of more astonlsh-
ing Workmanship, simplicity and sagacity,
in beings coming from the hand OF the Au-
thor of creation. If navigation is justly
deemed the most daring enterprise, 1T may
be considered as remedy against pride, to
know that there exists g worm, which an al
powerful Providence has at once made a
navigator and ship, hydrostatic and pu-
epneumatic engine, being destitute OF
mind. and vet one that watches the winds
and rides on the waves.

The Thames Tunnei The large timber
raft intended to lie OH the bed of the river,
over the leak, was let down late on Wcdnes
day evening. The engine was set to WORK
as soon as it was ascertained that the raft
lay on the bottom, and when they had sue
ceedcd in reducing the water some FIVE or
SIX feet in the tannel, it was discovered that
al further attic 'npts At reduction were use
less. 1t was then tried whether by stopping
he working of the steam engine the height
q the water in the tunnel and shaft would
increase or diminish, and the result was
gradual, but unremltting increase. At an
earIy hour yesterday, one or two descents in
Tie diving bell were made with view to
sec the cause of the failure, and Mr. Brunei,
INC younger, reported that the raft did not
nc on the bed Of the river. that it had drift
ed some distance from the leakv spot. A.
nong the many proposed plans to obviate

full articles.headline: ACTIVE BENEVOLENCE.
full articles.article:
The citizens of Providence. Rhode Island,
says the New-York Christian Advocate,
sent an agent to this city, last week. who
purchased a quantity os DR.. Chambers
medicine, for the use of such unfortunate
victims of intemperance as are unable to
procure it themselves. The agent related
to us several affecting instances of its res
toratlve powers. A man who had long beeu
confirmed drunkard, by using the med-
cine four days, was thoroughly reclaimed,
and is now perfectly temperate. and very
Industrious and respectable. Another. an
ingenious mechanic. who. in consequence OF
his incorporate habits, had forfeited the
confidence OF the public, has t;een restored
to his family and to society, and is now
proitaby employed, with several men nn-
der his direction. Many other instances the
agent mentioned ofts salutary effects, The
citizens of Providence have set an example
which is worthy of universal imitation
And it gives us pleasure to state, that the
Captain of tine steamboat Washington Of
fered free passage to their agent, as soon
as he understood the benevolent object oi
his mission

full articles.headline: Public Meeting.
full articles.article:
| Pursuant to public notice, large and respect
able meeting of the Democratic Republican
friends of the Administration of the General Gov
ernmert in Newcastle County, assembled at
the Red Lion Inn on Saturday the 18th day Of
July, when


Gen. WILLIAM CooCH, was called so the
chair, and GIDEON JAoUEs, was appointed Sec
retaiy.


After very suitable and lucid EXPOSITION of the
object Of the meeting, by DR.. Arnold Naudain,
II was, on motion,


HeSolred, That Committee of five be ap.
pointed by the Chairman, for the purpose of re-
porting resolutions for the consideration of this
meeting


In pursuance whereof, the chairman appoint
cd Messrs. Arnold Naudain, Wm p. l,robson,
John Higgins, VIM. Kennedy, and Alexander
Crawford.


The committee reported the following resolu-
tons, which, after some explanatory remarks.
were unanimously adopted.


Resoiuea, That We recognize in John Quincy
Adams Statesman Of unquestioned abilities, of
great experience and of rreproachable charac-
ter; who has enjoyed the confidence of WASH
ington, Jefferson, Madison and Monroe, in long
course Of meritorous and active public service,
eminently calculated to prepare for the duties of
the first civil Office in the country; whose pri-
vate life, in all its relations, presents example





overlooked in the selection of Republican
Chief Magistrate; that in reviewing the measures
Of his administration we can discover no act
whatever which do not meet our decided ap-
| probation, and that we will, therefore, use all
fair and honorable means to support his admins
traton, and to secure his reelection.
Res0ioed, That the appointment of HeNry
Clay to the office of Secretary of State, was but
a tribute due to the high character, splendid
talents and ardent patriotism of that great and
distinguished Satesman--that the stale charge
of corruption which has been founded upon that
appointment, is contradcted by all we know of
the most eminent persons it concerns, and by all
the circumstances involved in the case, while it
IL unsupported BY any evidence which would be
admitted to the prejudice ofany credi1able man
in society.


HesolOed, That the temperance, forbearance
and iirmness displayed by the President of the
United states towards the Governor OF Georgia.
under circumstances of provocaton and indigni-
ty Which we believe have had no parallel in the
history Of our country, give him new titles to our
regatd and appreciation.


Hesoiged, That William Cooch, John Ways
William =. Brobson, Robert Porter, Richard
Mansfield and William Kennedy be appointed r
committee for the purpose of corresponding
with such committees may be appointed by
the Democratic Republican friends of the adj
mnstraton in the respective counties of this
State.


Aes0ived, That the proceedings of this meet.
ing be signed By the Chairman and Secretary.
and published in the American Watchman, the
Delaware Journal, and the Wilmingtonian.


Reso!rcd, That this meeting now adjourn to
meet at this place on Saturday, the first day Of
September next.


wM. CooCH, Chairman.


GIDEoN JAouEs, Secry.

full articles.headline:
FOURTH OF JULY ACCIDEN rs.
From the Phiiadelhhia Gazette.
full articles.article:
We learn that on Tuesday evening, the
caDtsin aud mate of vessel from Folly
Landing, fought duel 7oith aces, on the
deck of their vessel. They hacked one an
otberin fine style; but some OF the specta-
tors having little regard for this honorable
method of settling disputes, had them carri-
ed before a magistrate.


The dangers to which many persons were
exposed on Wednesday afternoon, were
much greater than we were aware OF. A
steamboat that left the upper wharf at
Camden, weathered the storm with difficult
t. The water rushed into the cabin win
dow, the awning was torn to rags, and a
company of nearly two hundred persons,
principally women and children. remained
exposed during the whole the storm. 9th
er steam and team boats were Oh the river,
but this appears to have been exposed to
most danger, as it was feared She would be
dashed against the wharf, i'll which case she
would probably have sunk.


A boat capsiZed near the Navy Yard, and
If five boys that were on board, three were
drowned. The editor Of the U. 5. Gazette
says that he witnessed the upsetting OF an
other boat few minutes after 1t lett the
wharf Two young men who were III It, got
on the keel and were saved.


A young woman standing on the edge OF
South street wharf, awaiting the approach
of friend, was so much startled by the ex-
poslon of cracker, which a mi schicvous
boy threw at her feet, that she fell into the
river and was drowned before assistance
could be rendered.


At the celebration at Germantown, Pa. on
the Fourth If July, Mr.. Bnddey lost his
hand. This accident, we understood, was
occasionce by attempting to fire off can
non number of time in quick succession,
whereby the piece became so heated that
the man who had his fingcr on the touch
hole was obliged to remove it, The explo-
sion took place as soon as the atmosphe-
ric air came in contact WITH the heated pow
der.

The present Pacha Jf Egypt was very iesirous
70 obtain the luxury of eating ice, and there be-
ing no such thing in Egypt, Mr.. Salt, the Brit
ish Consul General sent to England for an appa-
ratus for making it. The machine was convey
ed on its arrival to the Pachas palace, and the
Nile water made use of for the purpose. Nah
mond Ali, hung over the whole operation with
the most intense curiosity; and when, after sew
eral disappointments, large piece of real ice
was produced, he took it eagerly in his hands,
danced round the room for ~ like ch j, and
then ran into the iIarem, to snow it to his wives
and ever luxuriatcs upon it.

full articles.headline:
IlI.1 WEI .sE "a csNsy ylgEAsa,

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.

Thursday, July l9, 1927.
full articles.article:
A most shocking instance of savage tero-
city was perpetrated on Saturday last, in
this place, by the mother Of young girl
assisted by a monster who had, tor some
time, resided as bo4rdrr in the house. l!
appears that the mother, for some trivial Of
fence, inflicted severe cOrporeal punishment
upon the girl; and not being satisfied with
what she had done. asked the gentleman To
finish the work; which, nothing loath, he un
dertook; (for we hear he had repeatedly
tried his hand at the same business,) and
with such effect did he ply his kicks and
cuffs that the victim Of their cruelty died
the next day. a Coroner's inquest was
held upon the body, and verdict given that
her death was caused by excessive beating.
The unfecling wretchcs have both been
consigned, by the proper authority, TO the
County Jail. there to await punishment
which IS justly due them

full articles.headline: SPHINGGuNS.
full articles.article:
In one ofthe recent discussions in the British
House of Lords on the Spring Gun Bill, Lord
Suffield said-"N longer ago than yesterday a
noble lord had informed him that a gentleman
had contryed very ingenius spring gun for his
house, by which he Mad shot himself, his wife and
his daughter" The Earl of Abingdon, in reply,
said she could not help rising, as the noble Lord
looked at him so earnestly, toinfor.n their Lord
ships that he had not shot his wife and daughter


A laugh.] lie wished also to state to the noble
Lord, that If he found him entering his house.
he would shoot him, and leave him to prove at
terwarls that on entering it he intended no harm,
and to find his remedy farb being shot" Ia laugh

We have read with peculiar pleasure, the
Grafton which was delivered on the 4th inst.
at Dover, by Wan Huntingdon, Esq. The
talents of this gentleman are we'll known in
the Co1rts of Law Of our State, and We
hope one day to see him occupying con-
spicuous place in her councils. We Intended
to have published some extracts from the
oraton. but as one of onr neighborlns prints
has already published it entire, we believe
il has, before this. been generally read

full articles.article:

and all persons Indebted to said estate, are re-

NATIONAL ROAD-The st. Clairsvllle,
Ohio, Gazette Of the 9TH inst. states the whole
line of the National Road, between Canton,
(Bridgcpor,) and Cambridge, distance Of a
bout So miles, has been opened for the admis-
sion of travelling of every description. The
line from the river TO Fairvew, so miles is paved
thst between Fairview and Cambridge is graded
but not paved.

In Florida, Mr.. White has been chosen q
delegate 70 Congress by majority of about
1000 oyer his opponent Mr.. GadsdeD.-It is
calculated by the increase in the number of
votes that Florida must have received an ac-
cession of 1000 inhabitants since the last
Election.

The body of female, holding all infant child
in her arms was found in the Delaware on Satur
day. They were, it is presumed, lost from one
of tho boats on the afternoon Of the 4th instant
The body ola man, name unknown, was oh the
same day found in the river, near the Point
house.


In the city ofNew-York there are at this time
pending before the four court no less than one
thousand and sixty cases. There must have been
some obstruction in the course OF lazy to cause
such an accumulation of troubles
On Monday the ID inst a fire broke out at An
gustA Geo. which consumed seventeen houses in
the very centre of the city. All the merchants
and shop keepers suffered more or less though
most of them were insured. This is the most
destructive fire that ever occurred in Augusta.


A letter writer in the National lntelligencer,
nvcighting against celebacy, says bachelors, |
wonder any man should long be bachelor -
Widowcrs have better excuses for not marry
ing"


A fellow by the name Of James Low, notorious
in NcwYork as rec liver Of stolen goods, has
lately been convicted of the offence He had
frequently been indicted beture but always Con.
trivcd to escape.

cr for every $40 inhabitants.

Of Quebec, on the night Of the 2tth and 25th d
June. The tender vegetables sustained consd
cradle injury, and the leaves Of the forest trees
bore testimony to the severity OF the cold
The present Attorney General Of England, in
n speech relative to the Chanceiy Court, deliver
ed on the 22l Of May last, observed that there
were then six Thousand certiiicated Attorneys in
the country, each making, on an average, thou
sand pounds sterling year by his profession.


The auction duties paid into the state treasury
BY the Auctioneers OF Philadelphia for the last
quarter, ending May, ii, amounted to S56,039
81 cents


II is said there are more than 400 billiard Ia.
bles in Philadelphia, ami 500 in New-York.


A machine has been invented for making brick
with great facility. One horse, by turning .
wheel, makes or strikes bricks as fast as three or
four persons can remove and place them. Two
persons supply the clay, one washes the iuoulds.


The Roman Catholic Priests, and the lnylncn,
Of twelve towns, in Silcsia, have pettionei for
leave TO use bibles, and to say their prayers and
sing their hymns in the German language, and
also that the Priests may be permitted 10 marry.


Mr. CL,Y reached his home near Lexington



public dinner is announced TO be given him ON
the 18th July


According to the official register Of the u. s.
Navy, there are 73l officers in that service, VIZ;
81 Captains, % Masters Commandanis, 22S
Iieutcnants, ~ Surgeons, 40 Surgeons mates,
IS Pursels, Chaplains, and ga Milshpmen.


The Ohio River at Wheeling was four and a
half feet above low water mark on Saturday
week.


The Boston Palladium, rcmarking upon the
sale Of Teas at Halifax, as reported IN the Pltri-
ot yesterday, says-"the prces are lower than
those in the United States--it follows that to
preserve our commerce, our duties on Teas
ought to be reduced"


NoLrA, one of the most celebrated phlloso-
pliers of the age died lately, in ltai, at the age
of eighty-two. lie was at the head Of the Uni
vcrsity of pavia.


Philadelphia has population of $50, 900; N.
York l70,0o0 and Baltimore 10000 inhabitants.


NJ. Onis, formerly minister of Spain to the
u. States, and ambassador of Naples under
the Constitutional Government, had died at
Madrid.


The steamboat Chippewa, which plies
between Black Rock and Chippewa, caught
fire on the 2Sth ult. two miles above the falls
Of Niagara. The flames were extinguishcd
with difficulty.


A Kentucky paper in speaking of isaac
B. DeSha, say:-"lsaac looks as well as he
did before he cut his throat, though not quite
so flcshy. He breathes through tube in
which he makes considerable wheezng."

John M'Lean, now Postmaster General, is

1t is stated that President Ho,ley, late Of
Trannsylyanii University, has abandoned
his contemplated tour to Europe, and is a
bout 10 take charge of "a seminary in New
Orleans.


JOIN BucKrEp, NJ d. adjunct Professor OF A.
natomy in the University OF Maryland, has been
elected to the profcssorship of Sar-
gerry in that Institution, vacated BY the reslgna-
ton of Granville Sharpe Pattison, ESD.


The committee Of the Royal Academy of Sci
cnces at Paris, appointed to allot certain premi-
ums for improvements in the medical art, have
assigned one Of ten thousand francs to Acssrs,
Peletirc and Caventon for their important la
bours relative to the sulphat of Quininc.


The prize of ~urgery, Of ten thousan francs,
has been bestowed on DR.. CIyIALE for his new

full articles.headline: ISr tie U5lmiag'on,aa.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Ejiitor-In your last paper observe
letter Of advice to the Watering Commit
tee, but as those gentlemen will doubtless have
enough to attend to without noticing the
wh,ms oil every theorist who chooses to push
forward his opinion, will undertake to in
form your correspondent @ that he is 1T
tie mistaken. He informs the Committee
that eve are entitled by the purchase to all
the water that can flow through certain
aperture, say 1o5 inches;" this, believe, is
not the fact--the power Of the mill is not dc
fined in that way, but if my information be
correct the mill is allowed a good and suth-
cient head of water for driving a stone of GER
tain dimensions, w..h the necessary ma
chinery for manufacturing -four. AS the case


is thus circumstanced, and the power OF the
mill thus defined, the Committee would not
be warrantable in taking the water until al
ter il had been expended on the wheel; and
as the pump will only have to lift the water
bv atmospheric pressure about four feet,
can see no serious difficulty in the case.
cannot see that it will make the machinery
much more complicated, or any more ex-
pensiye. If the water wheel cxert5 the
same power on the pump that it formerly
did on the mill stone, it is all the Committee
have any right to expect; and the quantity
of water furnished they must DC sa'lsaea
with, be it more or less.


As to the plan that has been adopted,
have no doubt the Committee have taken
the advice of those much better qualified to
iudee than / am, and perhaps as weli as
YOUR correspondent Q. himself I.


July IA.

Two young women, daughters of Mr.. Staf-
ford of fAlachuahender, Florida, were recent
ly burned to death by the explosion of a cask
OF Whiskey from which they were drawing
the fire was communicated from the can
die.

full articles.headline: NATURAL HISTORY.
full articles.article:
grass. hopper, which ilutters with So much
yivacity through our meadows during the
autumn, feeds upon vegetable matter. and
deposits its eggs upon vegetables, tor the
purpose OF being supported until maturetl.--
Before the grass-hopper takes wing, anoth-
vr insect, the ichneumon, alights upon its
body, and thrusts under its skin number of
its eggs, by means OF tubular awl. shap
ri uyiduct. These eggs slowly acquire per-
/ tectinn, become living worms, and feed up
on the body Of the hap!eis grass-hopper, un-
! I'll themselves are II ady to take wing. So
admirably do they perform their office, that
they 90 not injure the vital organs of the IN
sect they are internally Sevo' ,iGg, until they
are Just ready to change their state; and At
the proper season, hundreds of grass-hop
pers, in this condition have Just strength
enough rcniaiung to autter to a tree or
fence, and with Il dyingo fort Fix their book


ed feet SO iirmiy as to retain their position
long after death. Examine thcir bodies 1T
tnl, season, and you will find IN empty shell,
r one filled with large and active worms,
! just ready TO burs. their coverings aud be-
cone winged insects


| lac recently p'Ibiishcd number OF the
I North American Retiew supplies us with
!
! little kNowu to common readers, though said
to be familiar to the sight Of those who nav-
igatc between the tropics, the beautiful and
cnignatical insect, commonly called the l'or-
tugurzc man-of- war. 1t is from memoir
To Doctor Tlosns who accompanied Mr.. de
Kruscnstcrp, in his voyage round the world.


"Ihis singular animal hid several times
been delineatcd, described, and endowed
with names, yet not only its denominations
were various. but also the nature and char
actcristics asrubed to it. According to
some it was Poiypus. according to others
a Ioophyte, and others ranged ii among the
Mullusca. Naturalists who followed in the
steps of Lime, have called it the Physalis.
Wonderful as are all the works oil Provi-
dence, admirably fitted as are the several
parts Of each created being for their sever
al functions, complex in their composition as
they at first seem, while vet they are always
found to be really so simple and situable in
their action, on a nearer investigation. we
may, nevertheless, venture to rank this lit
tie animated creat"re among the most curl.
ous phenomenal. A worm between and s
inches in length, which is found but in cer-
tain latitudcs, has seemingly the skill and
knowledge OF an experienced navigator, and
is in itself Little 81 ip. Its evolutons are
according t@ the winds; il r Asses and lowers
It's sal, which is a membrane provided with
clevating and depressingprg ans. When nj
led with air, it is SO light, that it swims on
the surface OF alcohol. and is at the same
time provided with structure. which fur
nishes It witn the necessary ballast.


When ,irh winds would endaDgcr its ex-
iStence, it tlescends into the deep, and is new
e, Sc en- on tie surface Of the water. From the
under side ef the body proceed tubes, which
extend twenty feet in length, and are SO
elastic and delicate, that they wind IN sPi-
raj form like screw, serving at once as an
chors, defensive ard Offensive weapons. pu-
cunatic tubes and ferlels. The insect has
the colcrs of the rainbow; its crest, which
performs the office of sail, IS intersectcd
with pink and blue veins, trimmed with
rosy border, and swells with the wind, or at
the animals pleasure. The iibres contain
a viscous matter, which has the properly OF
stinsing like uettles, and produces pustli!es.
1t acts so strongly, that vessels ~ which
they have been kept for time must be re-
peatcdly washed before they can be used
These !ibrcs NAV be cut Of without dcpriv-
ing them or the rest of the insect OF the prin-
cipe of life; and the separation takes place
spontaneously, whenever the glutinous mat
ter comes in contact with a hard surface,
like the sides Of glass globe. The insect
has, however, dangerous enemies in small
dolphins, aud medes2, against which nei-
ther It's nautical skill nor IT'S poison can de-
fend it. To the natural philosopher, this
little animal is curious cxempliiicatlon OF
the principles of hydrostatics and othygrom-
etry, as its bladder is perhaps among the
substances that can be used for the delicate
instruments Of the latter science. 10 the
ihysologist It has some importance as the
rest of that class of beings, of which every
part is endowed with an uncommonly strong
principle of vitality, and which have there
fore not improperly been called biola by Dr.
Hill. To a contemplatve mind, the won
derful organization of the Physaiis must be
a new proof that hardly any great effort OF
human Ingenuity, perseverance,, courage ana
skill, is without duplicate of more astonlsh-
ing Workmanship, simplicity and sagacity,
in beings coming from the hand OF the Au-
thor of creation. If navigation is justly
deemed the most daring enterprise, 1T may
be considered as remedy against pride, to
know that there exists g worm, which an al
powerful Providence has at once made a
navigator and ship, hydrostatic and pu-
epneumatic engine, being destitute OF
mind. and vet one that watches the winds
and rides on the waves.


The great number of offences committed
on the Sabbath, have rendered III necessary

The bill annul!ing the marriage of Miss
Turner and l.. e.. Wakefield. passed the
House of Lords on the 9th. and was likely

idence taken before the Lords, was acceded

fender.


The Queen Of Wirtcmberg. sister Of the
King OF England arrived at Greenwich, on
June 4th, where she was met by the Duke
of Clarence.

est bed, though it is not often more tllan twen-
ty-Gve feet deep. Lake st. Clair is shallow,
scarce exceeding fur fathoms. Lake Huron,
Michigan and Superior, are in places, nine hun
dred feet deep, silking about three hundred

A letter of the Goth of April from Guayaqnil
saws. the United States sloop of war Peacock,
was off Guayaquil 10th April, bound to Payta,
had been struck by whale, and receihd good
deal of damage.

The Thames Tunnei The large timber
raft intended to lie OH the bed of the river,
over the leak, was let down late on Wcdnes
day evening. The engine was set to WORK
as soon as it was ascertained that the raft
lay on the bottom, and when they had sue
ceedcd in reducing the water some FIVE or
SIX feet in the tannel, it was discovered that
al further attic 'npts At reduction were use
less. 1t was then tried whether by stopping

gradual, but unremltting increase. At an
earIy hour yesterday, one or two descents in
